yagalib
Interface Environment<T extends Organism>

Type Parameters:
T - The type of Organisms populating this Environment
public interface Environment<T extends Organism>

Environments are the worlds in which Organisms live. By doing work on their population, Environments cause each Organism to exercise its Genes.

An example Environment might be a Casino in a Blackjack simulation. The Organisms in the sim would be blackjack players, and the Casino, acting as the Environment, would make each player play a number of hands of blackjack using rules/information encoded in the player's Gene objects.

Version:
1.0
Author:
Jason Michael
See Also:
Organism, Gene

          Remove all Organisms from the Environment

Method Detail

populateWithOrganisms

void populateWithOrganisms(Integer organismCount)
Generate the given number of Organisms.

Parameters:
organismCount - the number of organisms to create

reset

void reset()
Reset any Environment-specific state between generations. An example would be to reset all the dealers, tables, and card decks in a Casino. Note: it is important that implementing classes do *not* alter any Organism state in this method.

getOrganisms

List<T> getOrganisms()
Get the list of Organisms populating the Environment

Returns:
A List of the Organisms populating the Environment

clearOrganisms

void clearOrganisms()
Remove all Organisms from the Environment

doWorkOnOrganisms

void doWorkOnOrganisms()
Cause the Organisms in the Environment to exercise their Genes. Implementing classes should execute or cause to be executed the logic of the problem space in this function. In the Casino example, the Casino class might cause each dealer at each table to deal a number of hands of blackjack to the Organisms in the Casino, causing each to exercise the blackjack logic/rules encoded in their Genes.
